item.title: The real reason the cradle works the way it does
item.description: Newton's cradle demystified: the two principles of classical physics

media:content.media:title: The real reason the cradle works the way it does
media:content.media:description: Newton's cradle demystified: the two principles of classical physics

item.title: Testing magnetic levitation in a void
item.description: Electromagnetism: levitating objects without the resistance of air

item.title: Lifting negative mass
item.description: Exploring theoretical concepts of exotic matter and anti gravity

item.title: Does the fizz keeper really work?
item.description: Is The "Fizz-Keeper" a Scam? I do some tests and talk about the science and the dangers of pressurizing your soda with air.

item.title: Card throwing physics
item.description: The physics required to throw a playing card with speed and accuracy.

item.title: Have you seen an engine that runs on sound?
item.description: Explore thermoacoustic engines, devices that use high-amplitude sound waves to transfer heat, or use heat to generate sound and mechanical power.

item.title: Finding the breaking point of Stretch Armstrong
item.description: A controlled experiment to determine the elastic limit and ultimate tensile strength of the Stretch Armstrong toy

item.title: The loudest sound inside the quietest room
item.description: The principles of sound isolation inside an anechoic chamber, the quietest places on Earth.

item.title: Beyond freezing, the coldest sknow
item.description: Exploring ultra-low temperature physics

item.title: A room made completely out of mirrors
item.description: Exploring infinite reflection and optical illusions

item.title: The chemical heart
item.description: Why gallium pulses when touched by iron

item.title: What would a snowball fight on Neptune be like?
item.description: The extreme conditions on Neptune, including temperatures near -220 C and crushing atmospheric pressure.

item.title: Cutting glass underwater
item.description: The technique of cutting glass submerged in water

item.title: Spiderman's web is real
item.description: The incredible material science behind natural and synthetic spider silk, which possesses greater tensile strength than steel by weight.

item.title: Achieving zero gap between two steel pieces
item.description: In this video I show a surprising result about air flow at low pressures by putting a Metmo Cube in a vacuum chamber.

item.title: Ostrich egg strength
item.description: Through a controlled experiment, I measure the maximum compressive force required to break the egg, demonstrating its biomechanical strength.

item.title: Trying to break a floating table
item.description: Testing the physics behind the incredible tensegrity structure to find out just how much weight it can really hold before it fails.

item.title: Can water trap light?
item.description: The fundamental principle behind fiber optics, using a simple stream of water and a laser. Discover how light can be effectively "trapped" and guided through water by constantly reflecting off the surface boundary.

item.title: Exploring the strength of a spider
item.description: The incredible relative strength of a spider. Measuring the weight the spider can lift or suspend, demonstrating the amazing biomechanics of arachnids

item.title: Calculating the energy required to cook an egg
item.description: Discover how many drops would theoretically be needed to boil an egg!
